CONSTITUTIONAL CONFERENCE IN LONDON


    Order read for resuming adjourned consideration of Amendment to Question [6th June, 1956],

    "That this Assembly approves the stand of its delegation at the Constitutional Conference in London." - (The Chief Minister).

Column: 2026



    Which Amendment was, to leave out all the words from "Assembly", and to insert:

    "is of the opinion that the offer of Her Majesty's Government should have been accepted by the delegation at the Constitutional Conference in London as an interim measure, in view of the considerable constitutional advancement contained therein and in view of the urgent need to restore a feeling of confidence and stability to the country and to the people." - (Mr Lim Choon Mong).

    Mr Lim Choon Mong (Serangoon): Mr Speaker, Sir, yesterday I recounted the main points on which the delegation agreed before we went to London and I was coming to the time when the delegation agreed to give the responsibility of external defence and foreign affairs, except for trade and commerce, to the United Kingdom.

    The Chief Minister: Powers.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: Sir, arising out of that question, the delegation from Singapore suggested that there should be a Defence and Security Council which should consist of seven members. They would be one representative of the United Kingdom, three representatives of the Armed Forces, the Chief Minister of Singapore, and two other representatives of the Government of Singapore. However, for purposes of bargaining, the numbers were made equal, that is, three from the Government of Singapore and three from the United Kingdom.

    In addition to the above, the delegation agreed to allow the United Kingdom to have the power of suspending the constitution should internal security deteriorate to such an extent as to affect the efficacy of external defence or should the Government of Singapore act ultra vires the constitution of Singapore.

    Let us now compare this with what was agreed between the United Kingdom Government and Singapore before the talks broke down. We have read in the papers that the United Kingdom agreed to allow Singapore to double its elected Members - from the present 25 to 50. They further agreed to withdraw from the Legislative Assembly all Nominated Members as well as Official Ministers. On the question of citizenship, the United Kingdom considered the request from

Column: 2027

Singapore most sympathetically and offered the creation of the State of Singapore with citizens who would enjoy rights similar to that of fully self-governing members of the Commonwealth. Malayanisation of the civil service, in accordance with the Majority Report, was accepted in principle and details concerning this were left in the hands of sub-committees which never met.

    The points which were not fully agreed upon were the composition of the Defence and Security Council and the powers of legislation by Her Majesty's Government regarding external defence. Here you will see that the bargaining point which the delegation had in mind was turned into a firm stand. A suggestion by the Chief Minister that the Chairman of this Council should be appointed by the United Nations Organisation was not acceptable to Her Majesty's Government. Another suggestion made by the PAP that the Chairman should be appointed by the Government of India was not adopted by the delegation. A further suggestion was made by the Labour Front that the Chairman should be appointed by the Government of the Federation of Malaya. Having regard to the fact that the two previous suggestions did not meet with success on the ground that the intervention of a third party in a problem involving joint control by the two governments could not be pushed through, we took the view that this third suggestion would only be turned down and thereby cause further deadlock in the talks. We therefore suggested that, as the problem was one facing Singapore and Britain, it would be easier to find a solution acceptable to both parties if they could, by agreement, nominate a person acceptable to both. We were proved right when the talks broke down on this point. In passing, I must mention the fact that although our suggestion was turned down, we stood by the whole delegation as a solid front when the question was discussed with the Secretary of State for the Colonies. We did not prejudice the case put up by the

Column: 2028

Chief Minister even though we had expressed our feelings at delegation meetings that the chances of reaching agreement with the United Kingdom on this point would be slim. Our attitude has been twisted by the P.A.P. into an anti-Federation stand and later into an anti-Malay stand. This malicious fabrication on the part of the P.A.P. has been done without regard to the evil consequences which can ensue from communal ill-feelings. The public should know how the P.A.P., in order to obtain political gain, was prepared to sacrifice the harmony of the people and the interests of the country. Sowing seeds of communal ill-feelings is a tactic of the Communists, and I call upon the people to open their eyes and be warned against these poison mongers.

    Now that the talks have failed, we can realise the setback on the constitutional progress of Singapore. It will not be possible for us to have the great constitutional advance which would have been ours by next year. The Rendel Constitution, which was fiercely criticised, is still in force. The Chief Minister put it in London after the talks failed that only lepers would want to stand for election. I wonder what he will think of the present Members sitting in this House. The offer that was made by the United Kingdom was described as a Christmas pudding with arsenic sauce. If that were the case, then the present constitution would be an arsenic cake. It is therefore very interesting to find that the Labour Front has decided to eat this arsenic cake, although a few days ago a Christmas pudding with arsenic sauce was totally unacceptable!

    Looking at it from all angles, I feel that the breakdown of the talks was not at all done with a sense of realism. In fact, if we compare what we set out to get with what was actually agreed between the delegation and the United Kingdom, we will find that we obtained practically all that we had asked for. In fact, even the P.A.P. leader, who stated publicly that he had gone to London to fight for only 75 per cent Merdeka, was ready to accept it. On the question whether Britain should have the power to suspend the constitution partially as well as totally, he even tried to persuade

Column: 2029

the Chief Minister that if he was willing to give the power of total suspension to Britain, then logically and legally Britain could use part of the powers given her. However, we were told of a mysterious cable, and then the stand of the P.A.P. became that of a full loaf or none at all. This change of attitude on the part of the P.A.P. leader closed all avenues of retreat to the Chief Minister from the stand taken by him. This, in fact, was the true cause of the failure. Viewing the events in retrospect, I firmly believe that the Chief Minister would have agreed to the proposals by the United Kingdom if only he had thought things over before acting. The frantic bid by the Chief Minister to reopen the talks on his own personal responsibility was ample evidence of this. Singapore spent a large sum of money - in fact, $ 180,000 - on this abortive trip. Stooges of international Communism will, I am sure, welcome the failure so that they can still put up the appearance of fighting colonialism. We, the Liberal-Socialists, are of the opinion that we should have accepted the United Kingdom proposals and then continue negotiating to further limit the powers of Her Majesty's Government on the question of legislation with regard to external defence. It would have been easier for us to come back with 90 per cent Merdeka, work it, and after some time, go back and ask for just one or two more concessions to attain the 100 per cent independence. By that time, we would have raised our own forces for our own defence and the problem of external defence would then be more easily solved.

    I consider the policy of the P.A.P., as the Hon. Mr Francis Thomas once said, that of a young man in a great hurry. He wants to drive a car at 100 miles per hour through the streets of Tanjong Pagar regardless of the number of people he may have killed. No doubt such a speed will be most spectacular and will hit the headlines - but who will be the sufferers?

    As far as the Liberal-Socialists are concerned, we adhere to our stand. We view the problem in a practical manner. What we promised we have carried out.

Column: 2030

We declared that we would fight for a common citizenship for Singapore. We did it. We stated publicly that we wanted to safeguard the freedom of the individual and the freedom of the Press. We wanted to be sure that when Merdeka comes, the safety of the people individually, whether they are young or old, whether they are of one race or another, should be safeguarded. We voiced that for the people of Singapore. All Parties declared at the conference that they were aware of the danger of internal subversion; yet some were prepared, and, in fact, preferred to gamble on it. We fully realise, however, that Singapore is a commercial centre whose prosperity depends upon trade, which can only flourish under stable conditions and feelings of security. Whereas the other Parties voted for the breakdown of the talks, the Liberal-Socialists and the M.C.A. did not favour it -

    The Minister for Health (Mr A. J. Braga): Abstained!

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: We were right.

    Mr Braga: Abstained!

    Mr Speaker: Order.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: The talks should never have been broken off. The subsequent correspondence between the Chief Minister and the Secretary of State embodied in the White Paper, which is the subject of the next motion, seeking to reopen the talks, proved our point. In fact, these letters written by the Chief Minister provide all the justification that is needed for my amendment to the motion.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Mr John Ede (Tanglin): Mr Speaker, Sir, in rising to second the amendment, I speak as one who was, of course, not a member of the delegation but was able to follow events perhaps from a more objective angle, or at least from a Singapore angle. First of all, it is as well to recall some of the things which were said and done immediately prior to the opening of the London talks. For example, may I remind the House what the Hon. the Chief Secretary reported to

Column: 2031

hon. Members in connection with the Kallang mass rally, as memories are sometimes short:

    "At about 6.40 p.m. the chanting became more excited and a number of youths were seen working up their companions, lobbing pieces of wood, poles and banners at the police who remained steady at their posts.

    The police had been apprehensive of disorder because of slighting references made to the police at several P.A.P. meetings and because of the campaign in the Press by a large group of so-called Chinese cultural associations and students during the previous two weeks protesting against police refusals to issue licences for the performance of songs and dances of Communist meaning. These organisations held a further protest meeting at the Badminton Hall immediately prior to the mass rally. After it, at about 4 p.m., some 4,000 to 5,000 youths from that meeting marched in an orderly and disciplined manner to the rally. They carried a large banner depicting the Communist dove of peace. When they encountered police officers on duty, there was organised shouting of Merdeka. Their attitude was one of contempt for the police..."

    Nine days later the Hon. the Chief Minister, in a broadcast before leaving for London, said:

    "Britain wants Singapore as a prosperous free port serving the commerce of the world. This is the destiny we seek. Britain wants to keep Singapore free from the deadly clutches of Communism. We know that Communism in this mercantile island means death."

    Four days later, on, I think, the 16th of April, my hon. Friend's first act in London was to address "the blunt truth", as he called it, to Malayan students in a supposedly hush-hush talk. He stated, or so it is reported, that 1959 was the date for the take-over in Singapore by a camouflaged Communist party, and he had warned the Member for Tanjong Pagar (Mr Lee Kuan Yew) that the latter was inviting Communists into the P.A.P. On the following day he admitted in a Press release:

    "The main theme of my address was the dangerous attitude of a group in Singapore that is not big enough to overcome their bitterness against colonial rule and talks of throwing the White man out of the colony."

    On the 22nd of April, on the very eve of the talks, the Member for Tanjong Pagar took his turn in addressing the students, stating:

    "Our first task is to get rid of the white man."

Column: 2032

He was quoted as explaining that "the chance of one of his English-educated audience becoming the future prime minister of Malaya was 'extremely slender'."

    The majority of the Members of this House were away in London, but I can tell them now that the effect which these statements by the P.A.P. leader and by the Chief Minister had on the people of this island, already deeply shaken by the Kallang rally fiasco, was one of considerable concern, coupled with the growing conviction that the maintenance of full and firm internal security transcended almost all other considerations. Could there, therefore, be the least surprise, either in London or in Singapore, that the Secretary of State should state that Her Majesty's Government would undertake to see that this country did not become an outpost of Communism and was not this the logical reply to the Chief Minister's own fears? If this were not so, why should the citizens of this country not have risen up in their wrath on the breakdown of the talks? What has happened to the Hon. the Chief Minister's 167,000 signatories, who are supposed to have wanted his brand of all-or-nothing Merdeka and who, by their silence, have revealed that they do not desire anything of the sort?

    The Chief Minister: You are wrong.

    Mr John Ede: Sir, the Member for Tanjong Pagar complained yesterday that British opinion had hardened on the arrival of the delegation in London. The extremism of his own Party no doubt contributed to this hardening just as it had contributed to a similar hardening of opinion in Singapore, namely, towards the view that the internal security of this country must be properly safeguarded. Should it not, therefore, have become clearer, as the days went by, that if Her Majesty's Government's offer on all other major issues was acceptable, we should accept the whole, and was not that, in fact, the view of the hon. Member himself for at least the first half of the talks? The Hon. the Chief Minister complained yesterday that the final differences in viewpoint between the Colonial Office and the

Column: 2033

delegation were so small that the former should have given in to his demands, but is it not equally arguable that he should have made concessions when so much had already been gained? Is it not nearer the truth that the Chief Minister over-reached himself in the terms he tried to wrest from Her Majesty's Government, and is this not borne out by his subsequent actions after the breakdown of the talks? The truth is that almost everybody knows, including, I sometimes think, the Hon. the Chief Minister himself, that the British offer in its final form should have been accepted as an interim measure.

    The Nanyang Siang Pau of the 15th of May, I think it was, pointed out that "members of the delegation should have room for mutual toleration and concession and never allow a deadlock, as success could not be achieved all at once; and further, that if the delegates returned with powers of internal self-government, other difficult problems could be reserved for decision later and there was no need to force the issue now." That was the true feeling of Singapore. Those were the views of the village leaders, both Chinese and Malay, in the rural areas of my constituency whom I visited when the breakdown occurred. Indeed, many to whom I spoke went even further. They said that if the Member for Tanjong Pagar really wished to throw out the white man, there would be no Service establishments and no big commercial houses, and consequently no jobs for the considerable number of workers employed by these establishments.

    On the 15th of April, a week before this expression of extremism, the view of the hon. Member had been more moderate when he said on the eve of his departure for London that the object of the Merdeka Mission was not to secure full independence but 75 per cent self-government with complete self-government after five years. On the 15th of May, a month later, the P.A.P. was to reject the very large measure of self-government offered and to threaten to bring Singapore to an economic and political standstill, thus showing cynicism and an utter lack of principle.

Column: 2034



    With a fully-elected Legislative Assembly; with our own Home Minister and Finance Minister having full control of the police and the revenues of the country; with the details of Malayanisation settled and their implementation well on the way; with a Singapore citizenship established and an electoral roll fully representative of the people; can it not be seen that the complete self-government after five years which the P.A.P. claimed they wanted would, in fact, have been inevitable and very much more of a reality in even less time? Indeed, the Secretary of State promised a review of the working of the Defence and Security Council after two years.

    In our view, the greatest disservice which the Hon. the Chief Minister, as leader of the delegation, has done to this country is not merely to have rejected this considerable constitutional advance but also to have kept the one and a quarter million citizens of this island in continued doubt and anxiety as to the next turn of events. For far too long have all sections of the community been saying to themselves and to each other, "What is going to happen?" The feeling of uncertainty, of insecurity and of malaise has haunted Singapore for far longer than we can possibly afford. This country is not merely standing still, it is sliding backwards. The Chief Minister's policy, most unfortunately, has seen to it that this position of uncertainty is to continue for some months to come.

    The Hon. the Chief Minister told the Malayan students in London:

    "Singapore's economy is so delicately balanced that we survive only by virtue of the activities of capital."

His all-or-nothing policy has considerably shaken that balance. His action in accusing the Colonial Secretary of Fascism one day and writing to him the next and pleading for the reopening of the talks in those words - "permit me to express my admiration for your very real abilities" - was hardly a balanced action.

    Let us not only be honest, Sir, with ourselves in this House but with the people of this country as well, and let

Column: 2035

us match our own common sense with the sturdy common sense of the majority of Singapore's citizens. And what our joint common sense tells us is this: that 90 per cent internal self-government plus 100 per cent security with which to maintain it is a better proposition today than 100 per cent internal self-government plus only 50 per cent security with which to maintain it. If the Member for Bukit Timah (Mr Lim Ching Siong) cares to call me a colonial stooge for stating that proposition, then all I can say is that the bulk of Singapore's population are stooges along with me, if they were given the chance, free from the fear of the sinister propaganda and intimidation which the P.A.P. indulges in, to express their true feelings and convictions.

    The Hon. the Chief Minister knows very well that the Liberal-Socialist delegates urged him up to the last moment to accept what had been offered and then to go back later for more. He cannot, in any honesty, blame them for his own lack of vision, nor indeed has he done so. The people of Singapore are sick and tired of crises and this amendment reflects their real feelings regarding the totally unnecessary failure of a mission. That is the truth of the matter, and the tragedy.

    Question proposed, "That the words proposed to be left out, be left out."

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew (Tanjong Pagar): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am obliged to the Hon. the Chief Minister for allowing me to speak first on this amendment. For personal reasons, I will not be able to stay in this House beyond 11 o'clock and I was afraid I would have to leave this Assembly without having answered some of the charges made against me by the leader of the majority Opposition Party, the Member for Serangoon (Mr Lim Choon Mong), and the Member for Tanglin (Mr Ede).

    Sir, the People's Action Party, when we left Singapore, issued an official statement - 75 per cent Merdeka. Unlike the Liberal-Socialist Party, when we issue an official statement, we mean what we say. We prepared the ground for an

Column: 2036

agreement with the Colonial Office on the basis of complete internal self-government in order that we could never be accused either by our supporters or by our enemies of cheating. We fought strenuously in London to achieve this. Whatever differences I had with the Chief Minister were because I tried to keep the basis of discussion on the heads of agreement we had agreed upon before we left Singapore. Our interpretation of the agreement we had arrived at before we left Singapore was complete internal self-government. We wanted self-government. We gave away external affairs and external defence, and we were left with internal self-government.

    The Member for Serangoon said he urged upon the Chief Minister the illogicality of the stand of the delegation and of the P.A.P. in refusing to offer partial suspension of the constitution when we had, in fact, offered the whole. That, Sir, is a completely malicious misrepresentation of the facts. He knew exactly what our stand was. We went to London on this basis. We did not give away anything. We wanted to ask only for complete internal self-government because we could not have got more, because other members of the delegation, the Liberal-Socialists, would not have agreed. Having asked for internal self-government, it was idle to discuss whether or not Her Majesty's Government had the right to suspend the constitution. There is only one sovereign power in any territory, and as long as we are not independent, that sovereign power is Britain. When we are independent like Ceylon, then the old imperial power is out. When the Ceylonese decided to oust the British bases, there was no question of suspending the constitution because to re-enter Ceylon was an act of aggression. But until we have attained independence, Britain is the sovereign power and we have to accept that position. I agree that if Britain has the power to suspend the whole of the constitution, then, a fortiori, she has the power to suspend part of it. But that is entirely different from saying that I agree to the British having the power

Column: 2037

to suspend any part of the constitution. There is a fundamental difference in political approach.

    Sir, for three weeks in London I argued and I argued for a settlement. No one in this House knows better how absolutely vital it was for us to have a settlement if it was possible, but I found in the last week that it was not possible. I found that Britain had decided that she was not going to give us complete internal self-government, that Britain was going to sit in with the learner-driver. Britain wanted an Austin car with dual controls. Britain wanted to be next to the driver. What we said to Britain was, "If you want me to agree to have you sitting in with me, I want one set of controls. The day you take over, I will ostentatiously get out from the driving seat and you can be in supreme control. But I refuse to be your stooge, to be your pawn, like the Liberal-Socialists would have been."

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: Not at all.

    Mr Speaker: Order.

    Mr Braga: Of course.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Sir, of all the stupid things that people do, I think this is the stupidest of them all. They did not have the courage in London to say, "I oppose this breakdown. I propose to go on with the talks." Instead they abstained. Abstained from what? Abstained because they neither had the will nor the guts to make up their minds what to do -

    The Chief Minister: Except the Member -

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: - except the Member for Changi (Mr Lim Cher Kheng). [Interruption.] And now, three weeks after the breakdown, the Member for Serangoon said that we should have accepted the Colonial Office's offer. Sir, I can understand the Hon. Mr Sutherland and I can understand the Member for Tanglin (Mr Ede). They cannot help themselves. We are all prisoners of our own past, of our upbringing; our mental attitudes are values that we learned as little children. But I find it sad to see the Member for

Column: 2038

Serangoon - and I think, of the Liberal-Socialists, he is the man who most believes in what he is saying - come forward in this Assembly to be an advocate for the Colonial Office. There is the perfect stooge -

    Mr Speaker: Order, order. We have really been approaching unparliamentary language, but if the word "stooge" is used in direct reference to an hon. Member, then, of course, it is out of order.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Mr Speaker, Sir, forgive me for the slip, but I could not restrain my natural reaction at seeing one of my own people behaving in a manner completely unbefitting a self-respecting individual. Nehru said that when a colonial power succeeds in making a man think he is a slave, and he thinks like a slave, then the threat of power is no longer necessary, and the supreme achievement of an imperial power in subjugation is achieved.

    I can understand the Hon. Mr Sutherland and the Member for Tanglin, but I find it difficult to understand the Member for Serangoon. In fact, a lot of Malayan students found it very difficult to understand him. He went to one meeting and said, "We are Liberal-Socialists. Because we believe that the world should be a little bit freer, therefore we are Liberals. Because we believe that employers should give a little bit more to their workers, therefore we are Socialists. Therefore we call ourselves the Liberal-Socialists."

    Sir, they appeared before the Malayan students in London one Sunday and they never appeared again, although they were invited, because they accused the students of hooliganism. The students there are all idealistic; they asked the Liberal-Socialist leader whether he was prepared to fight and die for freedom, whether be was prepared to go to jail if necessary. He replied, "Do not be silly. All these things are unnecessary. Why should we go to jail for these things? The British are bound to give us these things and all that we have got to do is to wait for the hand-over."

    Sir, I do not know what to make of these people. They say that this is their Party statement. Therefore I assume

Column: 2039

that it has received careful deliberation as a statement of policy. It says the P.A.P. is afraid of Merdeka and the P.A.P. have done their very best to achieve their aim of not getting Merdeka by frightening the British. Sir, there is a touch of hallucination about this whole thing which sometimes troubles me in my sleep. I propose now to read from the "Suara Merdeka", the organ of the Malayan students in Britain. I think they must have been troubled in their sleep too. They quote Torch, organ of the Liberal-Socialist Party, which contained the following account of an inaugural meeting for the formation of a Youth Group at a seaside bungalow at Siglap:

    "It was a fine gathering, healthy young people having a pleasant and enjoyable day.

    Sport, games and dancing preceded and followed the meeting to elect office-bearers. Unlike the regimented gatherings of the young section of other political Parties, the members spent their time more on play than on business. The organisers of the gathering are to be congratulated for taking an easy attitude towards politics."

That is from their Party organ. I quote the comment of the Malayan students in Great Britain: "Those whom the gods wish to destroy, they first make mad." Mr Speaker, Sir, any man who subscribes to this amendment of the Liberal-Socialists must be going mad.

    The Chief Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Serangoon and leader of the Liberal-Socialists in this House, whom I respect as a man who always does seek to be honest and yet is torn between his own personal integrity and his loyalty to his Party caucus, has drawn attention to some of the ingredients of the constitution which the British offered. He and the Member for Tiong Bahru have made some play on the question of citizenship. I think they are conscious of how we of the Labour Front have struggled, with sincerity, with ardour and with tirelessness to get it. I do not think we need say it - it must be plain - that the question of citizenship to us is one of vital importance to Singapore, and I need hardly say that we have the people's sympathy with our domiciled Chinese particularly who are deprived of the right of citizenship. But, Sir, I am one who respects these Chinese
